data.title: Random VS warnings
data.body: There were causing a _lot_ of warnings in files that include them.

data.title: Stop precipitation from processing ticks when it's hidden
data.body: This fixes the crash in #1044. The cause was the precipitation calling `getContainer()->castRay` after having been hidden (i.e. the container was NULL).

data.title: Fix NaNs in Collada files
data.body: Thanks to [Jeff Yaskus's cleanup script](http://www.garagegames.com/community/blogs/view/22992).

data.title: '<hash_map> is deprecated and will be removed' in convexDecomp library
data.body:
When compiling with VS2015 community:

> Error C2338   `<hash_map>` is deprecated and will be REMOVED. Please use `<unordered_map>`. You can define _SILENCE_STDEXT_HASH_DEPRECATION_WARNINGS to acknowledge that you have received this warning. (compiling source file E:\code\Torque\3D\Engine\lib\convexDecomp\NvRemoveTjunctions.cpp) convexDecomp    c:\program files (x86)\microsoft visual studio 14.0\vc\include\hash_map 17

[This](https://code.google.com/p/convexdecomposition/) is the library we're using, and [here](http://codesuppository.blogspot.com.au/2009/11/convex-decomposition-library-now.html) is a blog post about it (note, the author has deprecated the library).

data.title: Scrolling does not work with SDL
data.body:
It appears the scroll control isn't acting on mouse input. Most easily observed in the world editor inspector. Dragging the scroll bar with the cursor does work fine though.

EDIT: this isn't a Linux-specific thing, but SDL-specific. No mouse scrolling works (weapon switching, for example).

data.title: overrides the default CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX
data.body: it was causing sdl2 INSTALL to attempt to output to  C:/Program Files (x86)/<projectName>/lib windows side, and  /usr/local/lib on linux

data.title: Removing pointless null-pointer tests for objects created with new
data.body:
Issue found with PVS-Studio:

Many instances where we would create a object via a new call, and then check that it was non-null.

This is redundant, as if we ever were in a situation where new failed, we'd be crashing left and right already, so the additional check is wasted processing.

data.title: Debug Crashes Torque
data.body:
On Linux compiled with GCC:
I don't know what's causing it, but if I choose debug when there's an error, torque just crashes. If I choose ignore, it's fine. I used gdb to try to trace the crash, gist below:
https://gist.github.com/avarisclari/d758bb054b2d058b786e

data.title: allowplayerstep lets folks run up sharper angles than normal.
data.body: That should be off by default.

data.title: Removes fatal assertion on duplicated object collisions (meshroads, primarily)
data.body: Removes fatal assertion on duplicated object collisions (meshroads, primarily)

data.title: adds minimum displacement check prior to convexSweepTest to avoid NaNs
data.body: Should note depending on bullet library version, this one may or may not be needed.

data.title: [Request] Stencil texture brush
data.body: Stencil texture brush for terrain sculpt and paint.

data.title: [Request] SMAA
data.body:
I would like to see smaa support in Torque 3d.
http://www.iryoku.com/smaa/

data.title: reduces rotation transmission size
data.body: from 64 bits per turret to 14 similar to player. they add up.

data.title: followobject position caching
data.body: re-use the position of an object we're following (within reason) so we're not constantly regenning a path.

data.title: Convert un-modified function arguments to const references.
data.body:
Issue found with PVS-Studio:

A lot of instances where some function args are not actually modified in any way, meaning that it is better for performance to convert them into const references. This prevents an additional copy, which can help performance.

data.title: Cleanup of ease functions operations.
data.body:
Issue found with PVS-Studio:

Many instances of a variable being modified inside of a complex operation. This could lead to unintended results depending on the whims of the compiler.

Resolved by restructuring the functions to modify the variable first, then do the rest of the operation.

Also some minor reformatting to be more code-style compliant.

data.title: Utilize ++iter rather than iter++ to improve iterator performance.
Unnecessarily repeated expressions
data.body:
Issue found with PVS-Studio:

Many instances of a function or expression being used repeatedly, which can lower performance.

Fixed it in these cases by creating on local var, reference or pointer that's used instead.

data.title: PVS Cleanup: Repeated expression optimization
data.body:
Issue found with PVS-Studio:

Many instances of a function or expression being used repeatedly, which can lower performance.

Fixed it in these cases by creating on local var, reference or pointer that's used instead.

data.title: fills in profiler timer fallback
data.body: as per remmed out lines in other samples. see https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/issues/1349 for report, and https://gist.github.com/Azaezel/2aafb88cf0d642418051 for result

data.title: Profiler does not work correctly on Linux or Win64
data.body:
On linux and 64bit windows, the profiler timing is incorrect. 
Profiles on these platforms will contain percentage time values < 0 and > 100%. This can be seen in the [enterprise profiler dump](http://torque3d.wdfiles.com/local--files/communityproject%3Aperformance%3Aprofiling-and-optimisation/profilerDumpToFile127904.txt) which was generated on 64 bit windows.

The reason is that the profiler timing ASM (in profiler.cpp) is only compiled when TORQUE_SUPPORTS_VC_INLINE_X86_ASM or TORQUE_SUPPORTS_GCC_INLINE_X86_ASM are defined.

TORQUE_SUPPORTS_VC_INLINE_X86_ASM and TORQUE_SUPPORTS_GCC_INLINE_X86_ASM are not defined for  LINUX or WIN64.

data.title: Fix running on Linux / Intel Mesa drivers
data.body:
This allows Torque3D to run on the open source Linux 3D drivers. There are still many issues but with this small patch it at least starts and is semi-functional.
- Explicitly request a GL 3.2 context
- Enable 'experimental' extensions on glew (This appears necessary to get glew to work with explictly set GL versions)

data.body:
I followed the instructions on the compile page to make the Engine, and when I try running the file it only outputs text in the cli with no window. I can't kill it with ctrl c either, and have to kill it from another interface.

```

Started up in 0.66 seconds...

```

data.title: Allow using ThreadPool synchronously
data.body:
Previously, a test was using `ThreadPool::flushWorkItems` as if it would wait for all work items to complete before returning. This is incorrect - see #1174. Actually, `flushWorkItems` just waits until all items have _begun_, so if you have long-running items, they may be still happening.

This PR adds two things:
1. A method `hasExecuted` on `WorkItem` to see if the item has finished executing.
2. A method `waitForAllItems` on `ThreadPool` to block until no items are currently executing.

This lets you use the `ThreadPool` completely synchronously, as demonstrated by the new tests.
